Hey Tim, I have a request and an idea for a video that you might kindly do.  I've been looking for details on the components that go into a Falcon 9 and the weights and dimensions of them but I can't seem to find what I'm looking for.  Specifically, what I'd like to see is a list of the major components from bottom to top such as: the 1st stage core, the interstage, the second stage, the fairing, the payload adapter, and any other component that should be added.  It would be great to do this for the Falcon Heavy and for the Starship when the details are finalized.  The idea is to understand what the weights and masses are from before launch through payload deploy.

comment_by: Prof. M. Otto Zeee JCD ECS
comment_text:
Tim, to compete with SpaceX launch cost/Kg (a factor of ~1/9 in favor of SpaceX), Beck (Rocket Lab) had to come up with something other than what SpaceX does. The only obvious solution for recovery is an air recovery system ARS, easily done with a helicopter 🚁 (since the Electron 1st stage is so light)...

So, what is surprising about that, Timmy? 😎

I like Rocket Lab, the founder, the team! Very clever, innovative, and there is a vision! They use vertical integration, print their motors, etc., use some new innovation... which SpaceX🛸 and TESLA have used from the start! Elon is the 🚀man. So basically Rocket Lab is using the same system and organization, which is easy, since they are small.😋

It puzzles me that you Americans enjoy speaking stupidity when it is the most inappropriate. For example, you are repeating something that is very much obvious, e.i. rocket has lift-off and it is obvious to viewer but you are commenting as that you are radio commentator and have to explain listeners what is going on. In the early 1960's we would stop on the streets and listen, commentator, explaining what is happening on the site. Today we are watching at the same time as a commentator and does not need to repeat what we already see. However, there is a permanent need for you to explain your audience technical terminology used by the ground crew and offer technical data and purpose of the flight, and so on.

Blind people usually have somebody next to them to explain to them what is going on, if they are interested which is very unlikely as they have no reference point to build an image of the event. So times of radio commenting are long-time went and no need to revive them when video speaks volumes.

As for the question about why they don't keep the fairing attached to the vehicle and land it- two reasons: 1. it's attached to the second stage, not the first, which is not recoverable. 2. it weighs nearly two tons, so that's two tons off of the payload capacity of the vehicle, and probably even more if you take into account the fuel reserve needed for reusability.


Since it's a very large object without a lot of mass to it, it has a very high ballistic coefficient, which means that it decelerates relatively quickly and easily on re-entry. It's much easier to just let it do that and then try to catch it.

55:30 Regarding not being able to see the stars: I think the answer we're looking for, is when the whole spacecraft is in shadow, like it seemed like it was during deployment of the satellite, why aren't the stars visible then? I think the answer is essentially the same as when it's in daylight. There are lights mounted on the payload attachment, so that we can see the payload floating away. The cameras showing this does also have an exposure set to catch this event - not the stars. If the cameras were set to be able to see the starlight, then the payload attachment and the payload itself would be all washed out. If the deployment happened within sunlight, the same thing applies. Here's an experiment to show this: Have a camera that can do manual settings. During daylight, take a picture of an object in your yard, and note at which settings everything in the picture looks right in terms of exposure and light. During night, illuminate this object using a flashlight or something else, and take a picture of it so that the object comes out right this time around as well. The third picture will be of the stars - take a picture where the stars are visible, and note these settings down as well. Now the task is to use these settings interchangeably to take pictures of the skies and the object. For example, take a picture of the object during daylight, but using the settings you applied to be able to see the stars. Most probably, the whole picture will be white, because the exposure is set WAY too high. If you take a picture of the object while it's illuminated during night time, using the daylight settings, you'll probably see the object in the picture, but nothing else. If you take a picture of the object while it's illuminated at night, using the settings you used to see the stars, the stars will be visible, the object will be mostly white, and the rest of the image very dark.

My point is that the camera settings you use are dependent on what you're intending to show in the photo. Here, the interesting part is the payload attachment and the payload. Therefore, everything else will be too dark to make out, which is exactly what we see. If SpaceX were to attach a camera on the upper stage with an exposure suited for seeing the stars, THEN you would see them. However, they won't do that, because adding cameras is not in their interest - their interest is to put spacecrafts into orbit and show us and themselves how it's doing.

If space deniers really wanted to, they could buy a CubeSat and get funding to put it on the next launch that carries them. They could have a camera there set to see the stars. There's nothing preventing people from doing this, other than money. If they lack the knowledge to design such a system, this too can be built to spec by someone. I think if every space denier chipped in, this is totally doable.

I agree, and disagree on stopping development on the falcon 9.
Yes its performing as it should and is probably at its limit of what it was designed for. Yes its probably best to start on a new rocket like starship, However. now that space X has reliability in getting into space, with or without starship, i do now think its worth exploring new experimental tech on the falcon 9. this could mean different flaps, or maybe the introduction of ion boosters, which are CLEAN.


i think its very naive to just just abandon something that is a very reliable rocket, when infact you could be exploring more avenues, for options, going forward.
Look at F1 cars. generally speaking the shell of the car stays the same, but year after year, they change the designs of the aerodynamics on the car, wheher its the rear spolier, the front spoiler, or the fins on the car itself. It gives you alot more knowledge if you explore different avenues and experiment on things.


It makes designing starship and future rockets far more broader in scope from a design perspective, when you have more options. for example. the fins on the falcon 9. is that the only fins they used? just because it works on a falcon 9 doesnt mean it will work just as well on a starship. having options to explore different ideas are just as important.

Tim Try this.
They plan from the end and work backwards.

Falcon 9 or any rocket for that matter has let's say 30K DV.
To land it takes 2K DV.
To do boost back to slow down just enough for reentry it takes 5K
For a boost back for close/nearby cape it takes 8K For a return to cape it takes 10K
So that leaves 30-2-5=23K It takes 26K to get this heavy payload to get to geo.
Simply put 4K is just not enough fuel to do anything with it. It's going to crash.

This is how they plan how where to start in the designs.
What does it take to recover? What are the average needs? What will it take to do that?
 If you start at the end. It's easier for people to understand.

Or you could try it like a car/truck.

If you drive your car fully empty with just you and no cargo. You get 30mpg/kpl
Now load that up with 5 people and all the luggage. You only get 25mpg/kpl
but here's the thing. No gas station along the way and you must make it 250miles/K on a 10 gallon/L tank.
Are you going to come back or ditch the car?
Had you been light with just you. The autonomous car would have been able to get there. Drop you off and come back to the tow truck waiting a little ways back.
